title: Moose and Swampy Cree Conversation Resources
description: Conversation Manual of the Moose and Swampy Cree languages.
author: Algonquian Linguistic Atlas

title: OldCree.com
description: Dictionary of derivational morphology of Old Cree, the ancestor of all Cree dialects, as determined by a comparative study of contemporary and historical dialects. Intended for linguists, lexicographers, and those interested in the history of the Cree language.
author: Dr. Kevin Brousseau

title: APTN Lumi
description: A number of shows in various languages, including Wapos Bay and Guardians Evolution
author: APTN

title: Indiginews Weekly Cree Lessons
description: A collection of Cree lessons focused around syllabics and SRO.
author: Eden Fineday

title: The Gift of Language and Culture channel
description: Tons of videos aimed towards children and immersion.
author: Lac La Ronge Indian Band

title: Kepin’s Cree Language Blog
description: Blog from Dr. Kevin Brousseau, largely containing Moose Cree stories and articles.
author: Dr. Kevin Brousseau

title: Untitled
description: No description
author: Unknown

title: ᓀᐦᐃᔭᐍᐏᐣ (Cree Syllabics) keyboard
description: SRO-inspired keyboard for the Keyman app
author: Eddie Santos

title: syllabics.app
description: Syllabics to SRO and back again in a very easy-to-use web app
author: Eddie Santos

title: 52 Weeks of Cree Lessons
description: Free weekly video lessons in your inbox, with the option to purchase the full course in advance.
author: Julia Oulette

title: Repeat After Me Cree
description: Julia has been posting phrases regularly on her Facebook page and also has a Cree course, 52 weeks of Cree.
author: Julia Oulette

title: MBC On-demand
description: Listen to stories and interviews from MBC radio in several dialects and languages
author: Missinipi Broadcasting Corporation

title: Indian Names for Alberta Communities
description: Glenbow Museum Occasional Paper no. 4 1987
author: Hugh A. Dempsey

title: Indian Sign Language
description: Published in 1969 by Dover Publications
author: William Tomkins

title: Tatooing Practices of the Cree Indians
description: Glenbox Alberta Institute Occasional paper no. 6 from 1972
author: D.W. Light

title: Elderspeak
description: Web archive version of the 2004 Elderspeak project from MLFN. 10 stories in nêhiyawêwin and english and another 6 in Dene.
author: Meadow Lake First Nation

title: giellalt / lang-crk (GitHub)
description: Finite state and Constraint Grammar based analysers and proofing tools, and language resources for the Plains Cree language. Used for the itwêwina dictionary.
author: Alberta Language Technology Lab

title: Maskwacîs Cree app
description: Great app with words, phrases, and games for kids.
author: Samson Cree Nation

title: Cree Language Map
description: Google map with pins showing where various dialects of the language is spoken.
author: Unknown

title: Plains Cree Dictionary
description: Another dictionary online, with similar entries as itwêwina, but without inflections (conjugation).
author: Algonquian Dictionaries Project

title: Online Cree Dictionary
description: The older dictionary (or “orange dictionary”) that is available both online, and as an app for iPhone and Android. Is being officially replaced by itwêwina dictionary, but still useful to have as an app on your phone.
author: Miyo Wahkotowin Education Authority

title: itwêwina (Plains Cree Dictionary)
description: The newest (and most powerful) dictionary for nêhiyawêwin, this online app can conjugate (and de-conjugate) making it much easier to find words in the dictionary. Developed by the Alberta Language Technology Lab and the UofA.
author: Alberta Language Technology Lab

title: Plains Cree Texts
description: PDF scan of the original book published in the 1930s. Bloomfield’s work was the first collection to use a standardized writing system for nêhiyawêwin and formed the bases for what later became SRO, or Standard Roman Orthography. These texts can also be found online at
author: Leonard Bloomfield

title:
Learning from the computational modelling of Plains
Cree verbs
description:
This paper describes the ongoing process of creating a computational morphological model of Plains Cree, a language native to North America, making use of
finite-state machines, and with a focus on verbs.
author: Atticus G. Harrigan et al

title: Wîcîhsok
description: Sênapân is constantly pushing out new content focused on language learning and targeted at learners of all levels. There are tons of resources from games, activities, docs, and videos to peruse in this Facebook group. Sênapân also generally runs a weekly online group, nîhtâwêwin
author: Sênapân Thunder

title: A Dictionary of the Cree Language (1865)
description: An early dictionary by the missionary E.A. Watkins, with Cree to English and English to Cree. Watkins developed his own (somewhat inconsistent) spelling system, so some existing knowledge of words is helpful in parsing out the content.
author: E.A. Watkins

title: White Bear Plains Cree Conversational Manual
description: Another phrases guide in Plains Cree, English and French from Beardy's & Okemasis. Originally Written for East Cree by Louise Blacksmith, Marie-Odile Junker, Marguerite MacKenzie, Luci Salt, Annie Whiskeychan. Adapted for Plains Cree by Jean Okimāsis & Arok Wolvengrey.
author: White Bear

title: Beardy's & Okemasis Plains Cree Conversational Manual
description: Phrases in Plains Cree, English and French from Beardy's & Okemasis. Originally Written for East Cree by Louise Blacksmith, Marie-Odile Junker, Marguerite MacKenzie, Luci Salt, Annie Whiskeychan. Adapted for Plains Cree by Jean Okimāsis & Arok Wolvengrey.
author: Robert Eyahpaise

title: Not Wordle - based on the work from Hannah Park and Aiden Pine
description: nêhiyaw take on the viral game Wordle, guess the 5-letter word within 6 tries, resets once a day.
author: Aaron Fay

title: A Cree view of Education
description:
”The
activities in this unit are designed to give the students an appreciation of their heritage. Doing
practical crafts like making snowshoes, paddles, birch-bark baskets, birch-bark canoes, birch
syrup, bows and arrows, slings, willow whistles, scrapers, moccasins, leather mitts, cradleboards, fish-roasters (apwânâsk), and setting various types of snares will show how innovative
the ancestors were to adapt to the ways of the land.”
author: Solomon Ratt

title: How to say it in Cree
description: Possibly a precursor to mâci-nêhiyawêwin, a PDF that I found on the internet somewhere quite a while ago an now seems hard to find. Archived here for posterity :)
author: Solomon Ratt

title: Nehiyo
description: One of Carl Quinn’s fantastic albums, all in nêhiyawêwin.
author: Carl Quinn

title: Cree Language Videos and Lessons
description: Resource featuring YouTube links to listen to different phrases and nouns. Also, there are different dialects featured.
author: Our Elders Stories

title: Tom’s Ramsey Story
description: A short story that was told to Tom Ramsey from his sister-in-law. English subtitles.
author: Tom’s Ramsey

title: maskosis okî
description: “As Little Bear goes about his day, readers learn AI verbs that might apply to their own daily lives, and how to conjugate those verbs to describe others’ actions in the third person (singular)”
author: Caylie Gnyra

title: 100 Days of Cree
description: This should actually be called 1000 days of Cree, there’s so much good material in there. Neal introduces both some old works and phrases, as well as some more contemporary words that have been devised by fluent speakers.
author: Neal McLeod

title: Brian McDonald album
description: Including the famous “tânisi song” and others, the full album is available to stream on YouTube Music as well as other platforms.
author: Brian McDonald

title: First Nations Storytelling playlist
description: A handful of stories in the language (including N-dialect), a creation story, trickster story
author: MFNERC - Inclusive Education

title: Small Number Counts to 100 - in Cree
description: Cree version of "Small Number Counts to 100", a short animation movie aimed at transforming math into a star in the eyes of kindergarten to high school Aboriginal youth.
author: Simon Fraser University

title: History of the Cree Language (part 2)
description: Conclusion to the two-part series on the history of the nêhiyaw people.
author: Reuben Quinn

title: History of the Cree Language (part 1)
description: A really great history of the nêhiyawak with an introduction to syllabics by Reuben Quinn. Don’t forget to also watch part 2.
author: Reuben Quinn

title: Wahkohtowin: Cree Natural Law
description: A great video with a lot of spoken language, talking about natural law, relations, and maintaining Cree culture.
author: BearPaw Media and Education

title: pê-nêhiyawêk: Come Speak Cree with Darren Okemaysim
description: A dozen lengthy videos covering two sets of nêhiyawêwin classes by the late Darren Okemaysim, featuring the TPR method.
author: File Hills Qu'Appelle Tribal Council

title: Cree Phrases
description: Neil present a number of videos introducing vocab and phrases, including the sounds of the language and SRO, a perfect reference for beginners from an advanced language learner.
author: Neil Redcrow

title: Cree Chatter Hour with Fawn & Dallas
description: A still-running podcast/radio program from CFWE where Fawn Wood and Dallas Waskahat talk about the language and introduce new vocabulary and phrases.
author: CFWE

title: W.T. GoodSpirit (Wayne Jackson) on CFWE
description: A short playlist of visits to CFWE from Wayne Jackson.
author: CFWE

title: Reuben Quinn on CFWE's Conversational Cree
description: A handful of episodes from CFWE with Reuben Quinn as the guest.
author: CFWE

title: University nuxełhot’įne thaaɁehots’į nistameyimâkanak Blue Quills's Podcast
description: Wayne presents a number of episodes from over the years, typically starting with a bit of a language lesson in the beginning, and ending with a story or interview from a fluent speaker at the end.
author: Wayne Jackson

title: Unsettling Your Language Podcast
description: A four-part podcast on getting started learning nêhiyawêwin by Chelsea Vowel.
author: Chelsea Vowel

title: mâci-nêhiyawêwin / Beginning Cree (online version)
description: Earlier (draft) copy of the fantastic book from Solomon, from 2012. Has the majority of what’s in the print version with the exception of some of the more advanced paradigms in the back. Released with permission from the author.
author: Solomon Ratt

title: mâci-nêhiyawêwin / Beginning Cree
description: Excellent book for beginners that covers phrasing, vocabulary and grammar. Workbook and reference all in one, and well worth the price.
author: Solomon Ratt

title: learncree.ca
description: Various printable (free and paid) resources including posters, books and learning aides in the TH dialect.
author: Lac La Ronge Indian Band

title: learncree.ca
description: A collection of songs online in the TH dialect.
author: Lac La Ronge Indian Band

title: learncree.ca
description: Interactive, online activities for getting exposure to home, animals, and other daily vocabulary.
author: Lac La Ronge Indian Band

title: Learn Cree with Me
description: Another great resource on Facebook (though you’ll need to ask to join), Cathy has also collected tons of resources around the internet, and posts videos regularly from her journey as a language learner. Definitely check out the “Featured” posts for lots of treasure.
author: Cathy Wheaton Bird

title: Nêhiyawêwin (Cree) Word/Phrase of the Day
description: One of the largest Facebook groups, and full of tons of questions, phrases, videos and other content. Posting still occurs daily, but you may find real value in the search feature when looking for various words and phrases (like hippopotamus 😆).
author: Wayne Jackson

title: Cree Simon Says
description: Facebook group by Simon Bird. Simon posts regularly various mnemonics, games, and memes to help support language revitalization online.
author: Simon Bird

title: Learn Cree with Andrea
description: Various videos on the sounds of the language and beginner lessons and songs in nêhiyawêwin
author: Andrea Custer

title: Cree: Language of the Plains
description: Paperback copy
author: Jean Okimâsis

title: Cree: Language of the Plains workbook
description: Workbook to accompany the language reference and audio sessions from Jean Okimâsis
author: Jean Okimâsis

title: Cree: Language of the Plains audio sessions
description: Audio sessions to accompany the Cree: Language of the Plains reference and workbook
author: Jean Okimâsis

title: Cree: Language of the Plains
description: A great resource for anyone interested in getting started with the language. Jean’s book is a gentle introduction into various concepts around the language grammar and structure, along with a healthy dose of vocabulary, and shouldn’t be missed if you’re just starting out.
author: Jean Okimâsis

title: Cree Literacy Network
description: CLN has been collecting stories and content for language learners for over a decade, with links to resources, books, and collections of audio and stories within, many hours can be spent perusing the archives. A worthwhile visit at any level.
author: Arden Ogg

title: Marjorie White ê-kî-pê-nêhiyawêmototâkoyâhk kâkikê
description: Marjorie White discusses her upbringing with the nêhiyaw language, and her ongoing Lessons in a visit to Blue Quills University.
author: Wayne Jackson

title: Long & Short vowel sounds in nêhiyawêwin
description: Cree Warrior gives us another kind lesson on the long and short vowels in the language as well as how they are represented in syllabics.
author: Wayne Jackson

title: Language & Connections to the Land - Wayne Jackson
description: A narrative from Cree Warrior
author: Centre for Race & Culture

title: How to Spell it in Cree
description: Document discusses the details of how to use SRO (standard roman othography), the most commonly-used standard alphabet for the Cree language.
author: Jean Okimâsis & Arok Wolvengrey

title: Plains Cree: A Grammatical Study
description: An in-depth look at the grammatical characteristics of Plains Cree. Explores everything from noun and verb paradigms to morphemes, to rare forms of words used in the language.
author: H. Christoph Wolfart
